title: Watch Jack Eichel score his first NHL goal in his first NHL game
text: Boston.com Staff | 10.08.15 | 10:32 PM Welcome the NHL, Jack Eichel. NHL, welcome to Jack Eichel. The former Boston University standout now playing for the Buffalo Sabres scored his first career NHL goal in the first game of his career on Thursday night. Eichel, a Hobey Baker Award winner , was selected No. 2 overall in the 2015 NHL draft by the Sabres. He rewarded his new team with its lone goal in a season-opening 3-1 loss to the Ottawa Senators. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below With Buffalo on the power play in the third period, the 18-year-old rookie fired a shot past Ottawa goaltender Craig Anderson. Eichel wasn't going to let down that Buffalo crowd! Goal #1 in the @NHL ! #ProudtoBU pic.twitter.com/ryg02742qq — BU Men's Hockey (@TerrierHockey) October 9, 2015 “It was a special moment. It’s something I’ll never forget.,” Eichel said of his first goal, via the Sabres’ Twitter account . “But tough to enjoy it with the result.” Meet the Bruins’ newcomers: Previous -- of -- Next During the 2015 offseason, the Bruins signed Matt Beleskey as a free agent out of Anaheim for $19-million and five years. With the Ducks last season, the seven-year veteran winger had 22 goals and 10 assists in 65 games. He added eight goals in the playoffs. Winslow Townson/AP The Bruins signed five-year veteran Jimmy Hayes to a three-year, $6.9 million deal. In 72 games with the Florida Panthers last season, the 6-5 right wing had 19 goals and 16 assists. Winslow Townson/AP Previous -- of -- Next The Bruins signed Brett Connolly to a one-year, $1 million deal. In 50 games with the Tampa Bay Lightning last season, the four-year veteran winger scored 12 goals and had three assists. He did play five games for the Bruins last season, recording two assists. Winslow Townson/AP The Bruins signed Matt Irwin to a one-year, $800,000 deal. In 52 games with the San Jose Sharks last season, the three-year veteran defenseman had eight goals and 11 assists with a plus/minus of 3. Winslow Townson/AP The Bruins signed four-year veteran Zac Rinaldo to a two-year, $1.7 million deal. In 58 games with the Philadelphia Flyers, the center scored one goal and recored five assists. He averaged 143 penatly minutes in his four seasons in Philly. Bruce Bennettt/Getty Images
